comments.commentBody:
"The Greek government has an incentive to make the crisis look worse
than it is."

If you lived in Greece you would think otherwise. How do you judge that? From a single macro figure, such as 0.7% growth for 2014? That is too pale and fragile to translate into substance for a society with one third deep into poverty, another one third collapsing much faster than they can cut expenses.

26% official unemployment (it is more), 25% GDP down the drain, half of the workforce gets paid with delay up to 6 months. Devestment, prices very high compared to wages, despite the deflation. That's because incomes dropped to 2000 levels (pre euro) but prices very much remain in the euro era, where most goods became 200% or 300% expensive overnight. We'll need 30 years of bad poverty to recover.

At the same time, without extra mesaures, Greece has to cut about 5% GDP of public expenses each year up to 2018. That simply is not working. We have faced worst recession and suffered the biggest fiscal adaptation in western history.

It is really hard to live here, and that explains not only the change of government but the unanimous backing of the govt negotiation tactics by 85% of the electorate. People would have to be crazy to want to leave the not-so-much-a-hell environment you describe.

Finally, political, social and psychological consequences of the crisis and such shrinking of the economy should not be excluded from the picture neither underestimated, which is too often the case.

The GDP per capita data for Greece likely overestimate the actual fall of economic activity.

1. Greece has a large underground economy, the size of which increased as
with time, and that is not captured.

2 The Greek government has an incentive to make the crisis look worse
than it is. Greece falsified economic data in the past, most famously,when
joining the Euro zone and might do so now.
Well said.  :)
Why don't you write one?

I came very late to poetry (over 40) but when I did, it was to Philip Levine.  I read his poem, My Father with Cigarette Twelve Years Before the Nazis Could Break His Heart (in "The Simple Truth") every day for months and each time I cried, until one did I didn't.  When I finally got the courage to write and tell him, he responded with a long thoughtful letter and a book called 'uncollected poems.  They don't make me cry, but today's news did.
Excellent. Real. Sad. This episode made me feel as if I was in my 20's again, not a pretty feeling much of the time..... The review is spot on, too.

I just so love your commentary. Almost more amusing than the entire episode. I especially adore those disastrous dinners as they bring on Violet's best lines. And only two episodes left?!! Say it isn't
so!!

The "one big idea" that can result in monopoly rents seems plausibly random. Keeping the machine going just requires simple competence, it seems to me, even in a world that is changing very quickly. GM managed to use simple competence to build a pretty good car company, for a while. Perhaps, humanity being what it is, competence in a large, complex organization is too much to ask for.

In the oil industry, the best, most interesting companies are those using the new hydraulic fracture stimulation technology well, and pushing the limits of that technology. Meanwhile, the incumbents are having increasingly obvious difficulty adapting. This is a case where fast-following can work very well, but a few firms, and especially the largest ones, have trouble doing that. Again, I think it's likely human nature: the skills required to formerly be successful are no longer required, and who's going to promote some kid to run a division the new way?

You obviously didn't know Levine.  He didn't have a phony bone in his body.  Many, many people loved him, and for good reason.  Yes, he had a comfortable life after a childhood of poverty and a series of blue collar jobs.  When he became successful, both financially and as a writer, he did not kick back and pretend to care about about less fortunate men and women.  Instead, he was extremely generous, especially with his time.  Many of those he mentored and nourished were blue collar kids from the San Joaquin Valley.  I know because I was one of them.  Having Levine for a teacher and a friend was one of the best things that ever happened to me.  I feel sorry for you for being so cynical.

Here, here, KGM1. I read imamn's words and thought, "who is this person talking about?" While I didn't know Philip Levine personally, I knew his work. How could I not, growing up in a working-class Detroit family? The honors imamn mentions come after years of struggle--if you're lucky--which many are not. Poets often work in academia because we live in a culture that considers it a luxury or, worse, a hobby of the idle. There is no idleness in Levine's poems, even when he isn't writing explicitly about work.

When I moved back home three years ago, I got to see him read--for the first time!--at the Detroit Institute of Arts. I cried then as I cry now, thinking how much poorer the culture will be without him.

Tho I don't mind Philip Levine's poems,  he was hardly an outsider or a working class poet. He put on these masks to earn a very decent living in a number of Universities peddling his craft. From Yvor winters to John Berryman to the head of the Guggenheim Foundation, these are the building blocks of the truly ordinary career.  Poetry is something more & the more is what is lacking. Behind the mask, the charade, the disguise, the working class comraderie, there is the smiling academic  winking.
What an intense story. I do hope you find the poem.

AG-- the poem is called "What the Writing Students of Detroit State Think of Philip Levine" by the Canadian work poet Tom Wayman. It was published in Wayman's 1983 book Counting the Hours: City Poems (Toronto, McClelland & Stewart)

Can anyone find a copy of the poem, What the Writing Students of Wayne State University Think of Philip Levine?  .... I happened upon it in the Library stacks in College - took a photocopy of it.  My ex-husband threw out all my books & copies when I left him one night, and I've never been able to find that poem again.   I think I've got the title somewhat right ....
Fresno is associated with some wonderful writers and poets, yourself included, Mr Arax.

Like Saroyan, Phil split his time between here and afar. Fresno, with its most concentrated poverty, worst air pollution and more gang members per capita than any other city in the country, isn't an easy place to do time. But it is a place to find the human race without a lot of veneer. That's what Phil loved about our town. When Phil wasn't in Brooklyn, I'd find him three days a week at our gym on Blackstone Avenue. He was one of the fittest 87-year-olds around. He'd lift real weights and then ride the stationary bike, his head down in a book of Keats or William Carlos Williams. Only a handful of folks at the gym knew who he was. To them, he was just a fit older man. If they didn't know he was one of the finest poets in America, he saw no need to inform them. That said, he did have an ego, and it made him a great storyteller. You'd be surprised what he would tell you in between sets. He was a first-class listener, and his B.S. detector was one of the most acute I've ever encountered.... I'm going to miss him.

Philip Levine wrote poetry that was plan, heartfelt, and deep.  He could take something or someplace so ordinary and make of it a thing that would take your breath away.  I mourn his death and pray for his family.

So the whippings will continue until morale improves?

The goal is to restore the Greek economy to health, not to punish an entire country's population for the perceived lack of good moral character on the part of some borrowers and now-displaced government officials.

Foolishly confusing the ECB with an avenging angel will almost certainly result in Greece's withdrawal from the eurozone, and even pose a threat to the continued viability of the euro. If that happens, member countries with heavy trade surpluses can expect their own economies to suffer as the resulting higher cost of their exports abroad dramatically decrease sales.

At some point somebody is going to ask how many divisions the ECB has.
Kind of hard to "pay the price" when almost a quarter of the workforce is unemployed.

I smiled at Professor Krugman's caption in his figure -- "Greece: Real GDP." How much of Greece's official GDP was actually REAL in 2009?

It is not just that Greece lied to the EU about its budget. My question is: How much of Greece's GDP was actually a bubble caused by Greece's fiscal chicanery? And how much of the fall in "real" GDP was really the hissing sound of that bubble bursting?

Then there is Krugman's claim that the difference between the two curves in the figure represents "Greece's excess [debt] burden." Krugman doesn't tell us what assumptions the forecast GDP made about the likely depth and duration of the recession, so maybe that accounted for the lion's share.

Krugman notes that Greece has achieved a primary budget surplus. Curiously he makes no mention of the inconvenient truth that Greece's economy was one of the fastest growing in the Eurozone in 2014. Rather than try to square that with his story about austerity, Krugman ignores it.

In any case, the Syriza government is rehiring public workers into what Transparency International calls the most corrupt public sector in Europe. Syriza's actions speak louder than its promises.

Here is an alternative theory: The incredible sacrifices of the Greek people over the past 5-6 years are largely the price they pay for their corrupt economy. No matter what the outcome of the scrap over whether Greece should be given another round of debt forgiveness, that bill will still have to be paid.

I don't see France as demanding an early exit from the Euro, but that could change as other's leave. If Greece's left of center government takes Greece out of the Euro, Spain will vote in a left of center government that will soon do the same. At that point there is no point in Portugal remaining and the last domino to fall will be Italy. One wonders what the loss of those countries will do to the rest.

Surely the value of the Euro in international exchange markets will go up and a country like France might find it too high to carry on.

The EC or EU is a Franco-German project at its core. In the past France's participation gave 3rd party countries trust that German chauvinism would be contained. Today they are relearning that German chauvinism is still a huge problem to be weary of, as it is uncontained in monetary policy.

The German question has been a problem for Europe since its creation in 1871. Partition seemed to solve that. Re-unification has recreated the problem. As for Merkel, she is overseeing the unmaking of the great postwar system that delivered peace, prosperity, freedom and democracy to most of Europe. I think she is a runaway train wreck of a disaster, exceeded in the post war era only by Bush jr.

She's insulated by the prosperity that Germany is gaining from the current imbalances. A hero she maybe to the German people, but then again, he-who-shall-not-be-named was once too, but history itself is more circumspection: she oversaw ruination of Europe.

Mary wants to have her cake and eat it too. She does not want to marry Tony but does not want Mabel to have him either. As for Charles, who seems to be a better match for her, she does not seem able to settle on him. She did not like the idea of him leaving for Poland for months. Maybe she likes the game of the chase more than actually loving someone. Matthew was able to bring out some passion and vulnerability in her. No one has since. She remains cool and brittle, and acid-tongued especially about Edith (who does sometimes deserve it).

It does not make a ? 32 yo woman "promiscuous" in her life to have had sex with three men, one husband, one one night stand and one "try-out" (he flunked). Time for her to consider a 4th, perhaps on a weekend in Poland.
lham, at that time, in that society, the one night stand could ruin her As could the test drive with Tony.

Actually, I believe we did see Denker and Spratt in the same scene either last episode or the one prior.

And Charles instigated the public smooch, not Mary. But she didn't protest, either. Perhaps Mabel Fox-Lane was right after all about Lady M's promiscuous latent tendencies.

Well said; we are all in this together, one Earth with so much diversity, a plethora of riches if we only pay attention, as you have. And the ants, among other insects, will rule the world long after we have extinguished ourselves. For now, life must be seen, and accepted, as symbiotic, we humans just a small piece of the puzzle. Sobering but true, hence, humbleness gets the credit.
Martin, I am now watching Downton Abbey.  It makes for a nice balance with the Bachelor.

Although I do agree with your assessment in principle, it was only 11 billion that actually came to Greece. The rest went directly to European banks (German and French for the most part and some Greek banks) that were already heading for insolvency.
That being said, the 11 billion that Greece actually received was for the most part squandered.

Reading Thomas' comments.

"Cassandra no. First of all: Greece has been received billions from its European partners in order to improve its economy. About 120 billion Euros - for 10 million people since 1981."

Brings to mind how a European News Organization, several years back, sent a TV crew to Greece to show the folks home how the money was used.

The crew went to a far and poor province and tracked down a shepherd who was given Euro 60 000 to augment his flock to the critical size required to compete the Eurozone. Shepherds and sheep alway make for good ratings.

The sight of a TV crew being something new, the village people piled up in the background as the handsome shepherd was interviewed.

What had he used the money for ?

"Well, he said, "I went out and bought a BMW"

But what about the receipts , the one he had to show Brussels ??

"Oh", he said, "I forged those".

At this point, the entire village chimed in: We all did it, we all eat the money"

According to my most knowledgeable Greek friends, of the 120 Billion, 1/3 disappeared in the pocket of the elite, an 1/3 was dissipated via small case corruption, and less than 1/3 was put to productive use.

Has Europe had its big idea, which has supported above normal rates of growth in wealth and income? Has the United States had its big idea or ideas? Of course, economic policy in the U.S. and the EU has been so awful and has so greatly hindered the growth and diminished the potential of the EU and the U.S. economies that it is impossible to say whether its is bad policy alone or regression toward the mean or both, which has resulted in such slow growth in the EU and suboptimal growth here.

But we can with certainty say this: Correcting bad economic policy and transforming it to what the occasion requires, i.e., fiscal and monetary stimuli in coordinated fashion and of adequate amounts and equitable distribution of wealth and income, would result in optimal growth in our economies' wealth and income and potential GDP, so that any slow growth after that would be the result of us regressing toward the mean, because we lack the big idea, e.g., electrification, railroads, the transistor, etc., which produce greater than normal income and wealth.

For now, my view is that our problems, i.e., slow growth, poverty, and unemployment, here and in the EU are the result of bad policy, not the secular stagnation of regressing toward the mean of mediocrity. China, however, may be different. Unless China finds a new trick other than cheap and abundant labor, it may be facing the normalcy of mediocrity before it can lift most of its people to high levels of income.

Oy, R/Elke.
Instead of being Al Kay-Line, Al himself would have been Al Kay-Seltzer.

I think it's time I swore off shaggy dogs.
it is the 2nd in this season,  ok batting 50%
it is actually episode 5 this season

It's spelled "minuscule."
And this was the best episode so far this season.

I kind of expected this subtle line from Mabel to make this week's commentary. After all, Tony's "tending" ("plowing," of course, would be too course) of those gardens has been a major plot line this season.

By the way, does anyone know if London had an aquarium then to which, perhaps, the Crowleys might take the tykes in the nursery on, say, a Sunday outing -- I do expect to see them (and us) see a shark jump before season's end.
I'll miss that quiet smoldering glance of Mabel's--can I get a cab to her series? And one last laser-guided barb: "Tony knows the gardens here VERY well."

excellent piece
but does dolan really differ from most of the other owners in nfl, nba, mlb?

Duncan the most talented power forward of all time? Hmm, interesting question. I guess you have to decide what you mean by talented. Most athletic talent with a high output? Probably Karl Malone. Best overall? Got to be between Dirk and Tim Duncan. But I'd argue that while Duncan has more rings, Dirk redefined the position's place in the game. Playing a pure four out game, with the power forward as an out player is sweeping the game.

San Antonio isn't really a pure four out team when Duncan is on the floor. He starts away from the basket, but most of his points are on cuts these days. Dirk can play cutting (less now) or from outside. And that is the four position on modern NBA teams, save a few like Memphis.

The Russians  paid $50 billion to host the Olympics, I'm sure they'd be more than happy to advance Greece $120 billion in exchange for a 99 year lease of some land in Crete or Rhodes to build a naval base.
I think the author meant personality, not career achievement
